38.spr_content: - Large Language Models provide instant information access; they transform knowledge consumption.<hr />- Personal knowledge bases remain vital in this context; they offer unique value.<hr />- A personal knowledge base is like a curated mixtape; it captures individual insights and preferences.<hr />- AI delivers quick answers, but sifting through irrelevant content can be inefficient.<hr />- A knowledge base reflects familiarity with material; it is a tool for precision in retrieval.<hr />- Reading and skimming produce different levels of understanding; mastering information requires deeper engagement.<hr />- Innovation thrives on unique connections; personal knowledge bases enable synthesis of disparate ideas.<hr />- Authenticity differentiates human insights from AI-generated content; the personal touch is essential.<hr />- A personal knowledge base embodies ownership and identity in a world of abundance.<hr />- Cultivating personal knowledge is crucial for personal growth and success in an AI-driven landscape.

39.title: Collaboration Guideline
39.description: guidelines for project collaboraton DF and Client
39.spr_content: - **Project Collaboration Guidelines**: Structure for teamwork between Development Firm (DF) and Clients.<hr />- **Tools**:<hr />  - Project management: Basecamp.<hr />  - Sprint management: Jira/Basecamp.<hr />  - Communication: Google Meet.<hr />  - Source control: Github/Gitlab.<hr />  - Design tools: Figma/Sketch.<hr />  <hr />- **Schedule**:<hr />  - Kick-off meeting: 1 session.<hr />  - Sprint duration: 1 to 2 weeks.<hr />  - Planning and review meetings: 1 per sprint.<hr />  - Daily standups: As needed via Basecamp or communication channel.<hr />  - Feedback meetings: Weekly or bi-weekly with Account Manager.<hr />  - Meeting notes: Disseminated within 30 minutes post-meeting.<hr /><hr />- **Workflow**:<hr />  - **Project Management**:<hr />    - All members engage in Sprint planning.<hr />    - Document milestones/features on Jira/Basecamp.<hr />    - New features/requests placed in Icebox/Backlog for future sprints.<hr />    - Bugs prioritized for current Sprint based on assessment.<hr />    - Aim for “Potentially Shippable” software in every Sprint.<hr />    - Bi-weekly review meeting for progress and conflict resolution.<hr /><hr />  - **Design & Development Collaboration**:<hr />    - Design: Provide color palette, font sizes, base components.<hr />    - Design review by development prior to sprints.<hr /><hr />  - **Backend & Frontend Integration**:<hr />    - Essential: API documentation, development/staging/production environments.<hr />    - CORS enabled on API.<hr />    - Agreement on glossary, naming conventions, and data schema within first Sprint.<hr /><hr />  - **Quality Assurance**:<hr />    - Bugs must include reproduction steps, affected platforms, and severity level.<hr />    - Dedicated testing environments for frontend features before merging.<hr /><hr />- **Release Process**:<hr />  - Releases occur at Sprint's end, with hotfixes as needed.<hr />  - Include semantic versioning, release notes, and known issues.<hr />  - Individual releases per Backend, Frontend, or microservice.<hr /><hr />- **Customer Feedback**:<hr />  - Response through direct message, email, or calls.<hr />  - Direct feedback to specific project team members based on areas (e.g., implementation, progress).<hr /><hr />- **Issue Management**:<hr />  - Timely response based on severity levels (Critical to Minor), with dedicated response channels and timings:<hr />    - Critical: 10 min response, 30 min resolve.<hr />    - Major: 30 min response, 2-5 hr resolve.<hr />    - Moderate: 45 min response, 7 hr resolve.<hr />    - Minor: 1 day response, 1 day resolve.<hr />  - Commitment to respond to all queries within 24 hours.

40.title: Fixed Budget Scope Controlled
40.description: Fixed-Budget, Scope-Controlled (FBSC) is applied at Atomic Object.
40.spr_content: - Atomic Object employs Fixed-Budget, Scope-Controlled (FBSC) strategy for custom software development.<hr />- Complexity of software projects complicates pricing.<hr />- Traditional strategies: "Fixed Price" and "Time And Materials."<hr />  <hr />### Fixed Price<hr />- Total project cost locked upfront.<hr />- Static: Scope, Cost; Flexible: Quality.<hr />- Assumes accurate estimates; risk transferred to consultant.<hr />- Conflict arises over scope changes; new ideas typically excluded.<hr />- Vendor risks losing money if project exceeds initial estimate; incentivizes rigidity.<hr />- Risk of building incorrect product due to fixed parameters.<hr /><hr />### Time And Materials<hr />- Vendor charges for every hour worked; no financial constraints.<hr />- Static: Scope, Quality; Flexible: Cost, Timeline.<hr />- Client assumes financial risk; vendor has no budget incentives.<hr />- Potential for unchecked scope creep, lacking visibility on project progress.<hr />- Clients may hesitate to modify scope due to budget concerns; vendors welcome changes.<hr />  <hr />### Fixed-Budget, Scope-Controlled (FBSC)<hr />- Combines strengths of both models, minimizing weaknesses.<hr />- Establish upfront budget without fixed scope.<hr />- Static: Budget, Quality; Flexible: Scope.<hr />- Assumption: Budget limits creativity; prioritizing best product outcomes.<hr />- Shared risk between client and consultant.<hr />- Regular reassessment of scope allows adaptation to new information.<hr />- Weekly project updates provide budget transparency and progress tracking.<hr />- Flexibility enhances product relevance; scope adjustments don't necessitate budget increases.<hr />- Collaboration fosters a better working relationship and improved final product.

41.title: Pricing model: Bill by hours
41.description: A new hourly billing model is introduced to ensure fair compensation for effort, flexibility in project scope, control over additional work, and transparency with clients.
41.spr_content: - Current environment: uncertain economy, tech market funding winter, cautious tech budgeting, layoffs common.<hr />- Upside: Companies seek end-to-end solutions, not just coding.<hr />- Expanded role of Dwarves: offering research, business analysis, consulting, solution design.<hr />- Transition to hourly billing model driven by: <hr />  - Fair compensation for actual work and expertise.<hr />  - Flexibility to adapt to project needs and client requirements.<hr />  - Control over additional billing for unforeseen challenges.<hr />  - Transparency through detailed time logging increases trust with clients.<hr />  <hr />### Implementation Steps:<hr />- **Clear announcement**: Inform clients of new timesheet approval process and time tracking.<hr />- **Timesheet setup**: Collaborate with clients to establish appropriate formats.<hr />- **Time tracking**: Utilize Notion/Excel for accurate hour logs; timely recording mandatory.<hr />- **Project management**: Maintain detailed plans; keep clients updated on progress and scope changes.<hr />- **Approval**: Submit monthly timesheets for client approval before invoicing.<hr /><hr />- Consistency and articulation are key for success in this model.<hr />- Building a habit of clear communication fosters stronger client relationships.<hr />- Operations team available for inquiries and support.

42.title: Lean Canvas
42.description: Lean Canvas is an adaptation of Business Model Canvas by Alexander Osterwalder which Ash Maurya created in the Lean Startup spirit (Fast, Concise and Effective startup). Lean Canvas promises an actionable and entrepreneur-focused business plan. It focuses on problems, solutions, key metrics, and competitive advantages.
42.spr_content: - Lean Canvas: Entrepreneur-focused business planning tool, derived from Business Model Canvas.<hr />- Emphasizes actionable insights and rapid development for startups.<hr />- Key components: problem, solution, customer segments, unique value proposition.<hr /><hr />1. **Problem:** Identify the central frustrations of consumers; articulate jobs they need to do and associated pains.<hr />   - Existing alternatives: Analyze current competitors and methods; assess failures to serve customer needs.<hr /><hr />2. **Customer Segments:** Define 3-4 key personas affected by identified problems.<hr />   - Consider job titles, industries, demographics, and salary ranges.<hr />   - Early adopters are crucial; they shape first iterations of the business.<hr /><hr />3. **Unique Value Proposition:** Clearly state what differentiates the product and highlights its value.<hr />   - Communicate target segment, primary problem, benefits received, and unique delivery method in one sentence.<hr />   - Structure: “We help (who?) achieve (what benefit?) by (how?).”<hr /><hr />4. **Solution:** Articulate specific solutions addressing consumer problems.<hr />   - Define essential features that position the product as superior in meeting needs.<hr /><hr />5. **Channels:** Determine effective methods for consumer interaction and promotion.<hr />   - Explore print ads, social media, events, or word-of-mouth strategies.<hr /><hr />6. **Revenue Streams:** Outline income generation strategies.<hr />   - Include pricing models, subscription fees, ad sales, or asset sales.<hr /><hr />7. **Cost Structure:** Assess costs associated with launching and sustaining the product.<hr />   - Consider development, marketing, and employee expenses.<hr /><hr />8. **Key Metrics:** Establish methods for measuring consumer engagement and product usage.<hr />   - Utilize metrics like SASS, AARRR, user downloads, and quotes.<hr /><hr />9. **Unfair Advantage:** Identify competitive edges that ensure reliability and consumer confidence.<hr />   - Leverage existing resources or capabilities that are hard to replicate.

43.title: Low-fidelity prototype: UI Design
43.description: Design systems enable teams to build better products faster by making design reusable, reusability makes scale possible.
43.spr_content: - **Understanding Prospect**: Analyze stakeholders, business models, goals, and challenges; ensure alignment on design elements like mindset, style, color palette, typography, iconography, illustration, and photography.<hr />  <hr />- **Defining Product Elements**:<hr />  - **Style**: Establish layout style aligned with target users; reference platforms like Dribbble and Behance for trends.<hr />  - **Color**: Define primary and secondary colors; utilize apps like Milanote for moodboarding; apply the 6:3:1 rule and limit to 3 primary colors for visual harmony.<hr />  - **Typography**: Specify typeface and styles (header, subheader, body) including font-size and weight.<hr />  - **Iconography**: Create icons reflective of branding; select icon colors from established color palette.<hr />  - **Illustrations and Images**: Apply visual elements consistent with content and style; use bitmap masks for file exports.<hr />  - **Platform Consideration**: Detail specific screens (desktop, mobile, tablet) and implement grid layouts to optimize designs.<hr />  - **Responsive Design**: Ensure adaptability across devices; consider user requirements for responsiveness.<hr /><hr />- **Demo Design**: Produce preliminary screens for client review; if color palette is undecided, start with grayscale focus to emphasize layout, text, and spacing.<hr /><hr />- **Design System**:<hr />  - **Definition**: A design system is a collection of reusable components guided by standards, fostering scalability and product development speed.<hr />  - **Building Steps**:<hr />    - Align teams on shared goals to establish vision and communication.<hr />    - Create design principles as guiding references.<hr />    - Initiate color palette development with moodboards and systematic naming conventions; implement and test colors to comply with accessibility standards (WCAG).<hr />    - Detail typographic rules: sizes, spaces, fonts, and usage guidelines.<hr />    - Standardize graphic assets, including icons, photography, and branding images to ensure brand consistency.<hr />    - Catalog design components in a pattern library by function (e.g., navigation) and states (e.g., hover).<hr />  <hr />- **High-Fidelity Prototype**:<hr />  - **Description**: Create interactive UIs allowing user interaction (e.g., button presses, sliders).<hr />  - **Timing**: Develop post-UI design completion.<hr />  - **Goals**: Validate design assumptions, present concepts to developers/customers, gather feedback for future iterations.<hr />  - **Tools**: Utilize Principle, Protopie, and Adobe XD for prototyping.

44.title: Onboarding
44.description: What we have to do when a new employee come to our team.
44.spr_content: - Employee onboarding as gradual perspective formation.<hr />- Commitment decision to company during this stage.<hr />  <hr />**Important Onboarding Notes:**<hr />- Initiate onboarding from the first day.<hr />- Avoid unclear expectations and policies.<hr />- Reject one-size-fits-all methods.<hr />- Involve all relevant teams, not just direct departments.<hr />- Onboarding duration should exceed one week.<hr />- Maintain post-onboarding follow-up.<hr /><hr />**Offer Email Essentials:**<hr />- Include net/gross salary details.<hr />- Specify onboarding start date.<hr /><hr />**Onboarding Email Requests:**<hr />- Set up Transferwise account.<hr />- Provide identity card information.<hr />- Submit insurance details.<hr />- Complete fortress form.<hr />- Sign LLC contract.<hr />- Create onboarding schedule.<hr />- Join Dwarves Foundation Discord.<hr /><hr />**Operations Team Onboarding Call:**<hr />- Clarify position and daily workflow.<hr />- Present company benefits, paperwork essentials, and cultural expectations.<hr />  <hr />**Key Discussion Points:**<hr />- Define probation goals.<hr />- Introduce team, leaders, and projects.<hr />- Establish personal 60-day plan.<hr />- Detail workspace tools (Discord, Basecamp).<hr />- Explain reward system (ICY).<hr />- Set up crypto wallet and GitHub access.<hr />- Share daily report and communication protocols.<hr /><hr />**Membership Integration:**<hr />- Self-introduction on Discord including:<hr />  - Preferred name and role.<hr />  - Project involvement and personal goals.<hr />  - Tag teammates for a welcome.<hr />  <hr />**Team Lead Meeting:**<hr />- Outline 60-day probation guidelines.<hr />- Set goals and review schedule.<hr />- Introduce new hire to department head.<hr />- Assign a line manager for support.<hr />- Clarify work scope and expectations.<hr />- Establish bi-weekly check-ins focusing on culture fit and workflow.<hr />- Encourage sharing within the Dwarves community. <hr />- Foster engagement in technical discussions and mentorship opportunities.

45.title: Offer Letter
45.description: The email template is to annouce about new employment.
45.spr_content: - Title: Dwarves Foundation - Offer letter<hr />- Purpose: Employment offer notification<hr />- Recipient: [name]<hr />- Position: [position]<hr />- Interview Process: Candidate performed well<hr />- Fit: Candidate deemed a good match for the team<hr />- Employment Type: Full-time/Part-time<hr />- Office Hours: 9.30am - 6.30pm<hr />- Salary: [salary] VND/month (Gross)<hr />- Probation: [probation duration] months<hr />- Probation Salary: [salary] VND/month<hr />- Start Date: [start date time]<hr />- Contract Type: Signed with LLC<hr />- Action Required: Confirm acceptance by replying to the email<hr />- Additional Inquiry: Confirm suitability of start date<hr />- Anticipation: Excitement for candidate joining the team<hr />- Sender: Dwarves Foundation

46.title: Hiring Approach
46.description: Hire people who tell us what to do, not the other way around.
46.spr_content: **Philosophy:**<hr />- Hire those who guide us; reverse roles are unfit.<hr />- Company culture stems from hiring, firing, and promotions.<hr />- Balance short-term evaluations with long-term vision.<hr />- Prioritize values and culture fit in hiring processes.<hr /><hr />**Principles:**<hr />1. Hiring signifies execution failure; seek assistance.<hr />2. Employee effectiveness in startups resembles a power distribution.<hr />3. Accept false positives; avoid false negatives.<hr />4. Culture is shaped by hiring choices.<hr />5. "A" players elevate workplace quality over superficial perks.<hr /><hr />**Heuristics:**<hr />- Favor strengths over weaknesses.<hr />- Consider potential trajectory over existing experience.<hr />- Seek doers, not just tellers.<hr />- Prioritize learners instead of experts.<hr />- Embrace diversity over sameness.<hr />- Bypass ego; attitude trumps skill.<hr />- Identify resilient individuals; obedience can hinder adaptability.<hr />- Assess habits; what you observe now persists.<hr />- A sense of humor indicates adaptability and engagement.<hr />- Fill skill gaps in existing teams; enhance diversity.<hr />- Maintain a "bullpen" of potential hires continuously.<hr />- Look for intellectual curiosity and communicative competence.<hr />- Emphasize the importance of diversity; widen recruitment strategies.<hr /><hr />**Protecting vs. Growing Culture:**<hr />- Hiring often serves to maintain existing cultures; avoid gatekeeping.<hr />- Embrace a dynamic culture that evolves with business growth.<hr />- Seek culture-adders, not just culture-fitters, to enhance dynamics.<hr /><hr />**Culture Add, Not Culture Fit:**<hr />- Culture fit is vital; avoid hiring identical candidates.<hr />- Diversity fosters innovation and varied problem-solving approaches.<hr />- Prioritize listening in interviews—focus on candidates' narratives.<hr />- Avoid impulse in hiring; maintain quality standards over urgency.<hr />- Emphasize continuous recruitment from diverse environments.<hr /><hr />**Offering:**<hr />- Act quickly with suitable candidates; clarity is key in offers.<hr />- Preserve relationships with candidates who decline; future opportunities may arise.

47.title: How People Matter Should Work
47.description: A philosophical exploration of authentic employee engagement in software companies, focusing on individual contributions, unconventional hiring practices, knowledge sharing culture, and intrinsic motivation rather than superficial happiness metrics.
47.spr_content: - Central thesis: People are the core of business, emphasized in various articles.<hr />- Common narrative: Importance of HR in nurturing talent and fostering engagement.<hr />- Critique: Excessive focus on "how-tos" detracts from genuine value.<hr />- Authenticity over happiness: Real engagement springs from belief in one’s contributions, not merely superficial happiness.<hr />  <hr />- Individual Contribution: <hr />  - Automatic check-ins reveal pride in work.<hr />  - Acknowledgment is vital; recognize the creators behind products.<hr /><hr />- Unconventional hiring approach:<hr />  - Non-traditional backgrounds encouraged; skill over diploma.<hr />  - Value diverse experiences; focus on mindset aligned with engineering vision.<hr />  <hr />- Knowledge Sharing Culture:<hr />  - Informal, driven by curiosity and desire to assist.<hr />  - Team members intrinsically motivated to share knowledge, fostering collective growth.<hr /><hr />- People-driven culture:<hr />  - Incentives matter less than intrinsic motivation; people stay if they choose to.<hr />  - Create an inspiring environment that values contributions, fairness, and open dialogue.<hr />- Focus on fostering a space where personal and collective purposes align.

48.title: How to conduct delivery reports
48.description: How we conduct insightful delivery reports that ensure transparency, improve team performance, and enhance client relationships
48.spr_content: - Goal: Efficient resource allocation, task assignment, issue resolution.<hr />- Report questions: <hr />  1. Did we help the client achieve their targets?<hr />  2. How did the team perform?<hr />  3. Are there any problems needing resolution?<hr /><hr />### Process Overview:<hr />- **Data Gathering:**<hr />  - **Artifact Collection:** <hr />    - Collect proof of work: demo materials, updated documents, project logs.<hr />    - Identify technical and managerial issues.<hr /><hr />- **Team Performance Evaluation:**<hr />  - Assess account managers' client advocacy.<hr />  - Review tech leads' consultation and delivery management.<hr />  - Evaluate individual team member workload and performance.<hr /><hr />- **Project Priority Assessment:**<hr />  - Rank projects by deal size, opportunity potential, and strategic importance.<hr /><hr />### Report Compilation:<hr />- **Project Sorting by Importance:** Rank projects by priority.<hr />- **Client Happiness & Performance Ratings:** Rate satisfaction and performance on a scale of 1 to 5.<hr />- **Issues & Resolutions Logs:** Document encountered issues and implemented solutions.

49.title: How we do effective planning and reporting
49.description: How we do effective planning and reporting at Dwarves
49.spr_content: - **Borderless Company**: Encourages remote work, emphasizes clear communication.<hr />- **Structured Workflow**: Ensures efficient weekly work allocation for team synchronization and timely task completion.<hr />  <hr />### Weekly Planning & Retro<hr />- **Purpose**: Set priorities, align members, and track progress towards monthly goals.<hr />- **Agenda**: <hr />  - Customizable by teams, includes updates, task prioritization, blockers, lessons learned, and weekly goals.<hr />- **Planning Session**:<hr />  - Combined retrospective and planning to minimize meetings.<hr />  - **Participants**: All team members required.<hr />  - **Timing**: Friday afternoon or Monday morning.<hr />  - **Format**: Conducted via Discord voice channel.<hr />  - **Preparation**: Written weekly plan submission before meetings.<hr /><hr />### Weekly Reporting<hr />- **Objective**: Show progress, celebrate achievements, and address challenges.<hr />- **Preparation**: Written reports submitted before the planning session.<hr />- **Focus**: Quality of tasks, challenges/issues, lessons learned, and team contributions.<hr /><hr />### Daily Check-in<hr />- **Timing**: End of each working day, no later than 6 PM.<hr />- **Format**: Standups or written checks depending on team dynamics; brief and focused.<hr />- **Contents**:<hr />  - Daily plan vs. accomplishment.<hr />  - Obstacles to progress.<hr />  - Support needed from team members.<hr />  - Takeaways and lessons learned.<hr /><hr />### Summary<hr />- **Minimum Requirements** for a working week at Dwarves:<hr />  - **Weekly Planning**: Bullet point written plan & meeting at week start/week end.<hr />  - **Weekly Report**: Bullet point written report highlighting progress, challenges, and lessons.<hr />  - **Daily Check-in**: Written check-in at day's end.

50.title: OGIF - Oh God It's Friday
50.description: I would like to introduce to you our new initiative called **OGIF** ,  Oh God It's Friday. Moving forward, our Friday Showcase will have a broader range of topics to discuss and share.
50.spr_content: - Initiative: **OGIF (Oh God It's Friday)**; broaden Friday Showcase topics.<hr />- Reflect: Achievements of the past week; embrace optimism for the future.<hr />- Core Value: Work-life balance; prioritize responsibilities first.<hr />- Work Culture: Foster hard work and provide growth opportunities.<hr />- Redefine TGIF: Not an escape; pursue passion and interests.<hr />- 70/50 Culture: 70% work duties, 50% personal growth; 30% pursue side projects.<hr />- Goal: Positive societal impact; sustainable income through dedication.<hr />- Achievements: 20+ software shipped; collaboration with 20+ clients.<hr />- Graduates excel beyond Dwarves; continued success in careers.<hr />- Open Discussions: Growth opportunities in tech, social development, finance, career paths.<hr />- Community: Welcoming space for diverse opinions; appreciate accomplishments.<hr />- Motto: "TGIF sometimes, OGIF all the time." <hr />- Cheers!

51.title: Our Policy For Remote Working
51.description: Some useful practices we adopted to keep the remote working system goes smoothly. This policy is written in the context of our current company setup.
51.spr_content: - Remote work policy for a full-remote team. <hr />- Accountability remains high for remote and in-office employees. <hr />- Accommodate time zone differences in scheduling meetings. <hr />- Guidelines and tools facilitate effective remote work; personal initiative is essential.<hr />  <hr />**Adoption Practices:**<hr />- **Plan & Prepare:** Ensure strong Wi-Fi, distraction-free space, privacy for calls, and readiness for a full workday.<hr />- **Proactive Check-ins:** Use tools like Slack for availability and project updates; maintain communication.<hr />  <hr />**Calendar Management:**<hr />- Update calendar with remote work locations and availability.<hr /><hr />**Extended Remote Work:**<hr />- Notify about extended remote work (over 3 days), privileges demand proven effectiveness.<hr />- Manager approval required for non-home remote work.<hr /><hr />**Schedule Communication:**<hr />- Inform team at least 3 days in advance about remote work plans:<hr />  - Post notifications in #office.<hr />  - Verbally notify close colleagues.<hr />  - Update calendar.<hr /><hr />**Meeting Protocols:**<hr />- Timely meeting starts are mandatory for all participants.<hr />- Scheduled meetings should be within regular hours (10:30am - 1:00pm).<hr />- Video options for remote participants are standard; audio only by exception.<hr /><hr />**Managerial Oversight:**<hr />- Remote work is a privilege; non-compliance can lead to revocation.<hr />- Regular 1:1s focus on remote work challenges and responsibilities; fosters open feedback.

52.title: Setup email template in Gmail
52.description: How to setup template for email in Gmail
52.spr_content: - Enable Gmail Canned Responses:  <hr />    - Login to Gmail.  <hr />    - Navigate to Settings -> Settings -> Advanced tab.  <hr />    - Activate Canned Responses (Templates) to **Enabled**.  <hr /><hr />- Manage Templates:  <hr />    - Save draft as a new template for later use.  <hr />    - Select an existing template for composing an email.  <hr /><hr />- Template Guidelines:  <hr />    - Highlight placeholders in *red* for easy identification by users.

53.title: How to swap ICY to BTC
53.description: A friendly guide to converting your ICY tokens to Bitcoin (BTC) using our platform. We'll walk you through the process step by step, from wallet setup to transaction monitoring.
53.spr_content: - Begin ICY to Bitcoin (BTC) conversion.<hr />- Requirements: Bitcoin wallet, ETH for gas fees.<hr />- Bitcoin wallet options: Electrum, Trust Wallet, UniSat.<hr />- For ETH assistance, contact Dwarves Foundation on Discord.<hr />  <hr />**Step 1: Connect to icy.so**<hr />- Visit icy.so.<hr />- Click "Connect Wallet".<hr />- Choose wallet (MetaMask, Coinbase, etc.).<hr />- Ensure connection on Base network.<hr /><hr />**Step 2: Make the swap**<hr />- Source Token: ICY; Destination Token: BTC.<hr />- Minimum swap: 20 ICY.<hr />- Enter BTC wallet address and confirm swap.<hr />  <hr />**Step 3: Track your transaction**<hr />- Track in "Recent Transactions".<hr />- Hover for details; status updates as "Pending".<hr />- Processing time varies due to network conditions.<hr /><hr />**Key points to remember**<hr />- Minimum swap: 20 ICY.<hr />- Service fee: 3,000 units per transaction.<hr />- Gas fees in ETH on Base network.<hr />- Delays possible during high activity.<hr /><hr />- Access support on Dwarves Foundation Discord for assistance.

54.title: How much is your ICY worth
54.description: Learn how ICY's value has evolved from a fixed USDC-backed model to a dynamic Bitcoin-backed system. We'll explain what this means for your holdings and how to track your ICY's value.
54.spr_content: - ICY transitions from fixed USDC-backed value to dynamic Bitcoin-backed model.  <hr />- Previous model: Each ICY worth `1.5 USDC`; stable and predictable.  <hr />- New model: ICY's value linked to Bitcoin (BTC) via liquidity pools.  <hr />- Two pools managed: one for ICY, one for BTC; interactions determine ICY value.  <hr />- Initial conversion rate set; value fluctuates with BTC price and pool dynamics.  <hr />- Key factors influencing ICY value:  <hr />  - Current Bitcoin market price.  <hr />  - Conditions of liquidity pools.  <hr />  - Overall market demand for ICY.  <hr />- BTC addition raises ICY value; more ICY lowers it.  <hr />- Example: `1 ICY = 0.00003 BTC`; if BTC at `$50,000`, ICY worth `$1.50`.  <hr />- If BTC rises to `$60,000`, ICY value increases to `$1.80`.  <hr />- Adding BTC to pool raises ICY value; adding ICY reduces it.  <hr />- Liquidity management: monthly BTC addition, weekly ICY minting for activities and rewards.  <hr />- Objective: Stability while allowing for market-driven value changes.  <hr />- Change rationale: Adaptation to crypto ecosystem, growth potential tied to Bitcoin, reduced reliance on stablecoins, dynamic, reflective of real-world trading conditions.  <hr />- Ongoing tracking of BTC performance and liquidity dynamics recommended for informed ICY decisions.

Explain the 'why' and relevance to team.<hr />- **HR Actions:** <hr />  - Review request and budget.<hr />  - Approve and order item if reasonable.<hr />  - Notify upon arrival via Basecamp.<hr />  - Mark To-Do as done once received.<hr />- **Conclusion:** Simple access to tools enhances productivity.

60.title: Submit a leave request
60.description: A consistent on leave process prevents a company from being accidentally disrupted when an employee request to be absent.
60.spr_content: - Clear leave request process ensures smooth operations and minimal disruption.<hr />- Discuss leave plans with client and team to align tasks.<hr />- Leave request submission steps include:<hr />  - Log into Basecamp.<hr />  - Create ticket in Woodland channel > On-Leave Request list.<hr />  - Format: Name | Type of absence (off/remote) | Date | Shift.<hr />  - Assign to: Project Manager, Account Manager, Project Lead.<hr />- Request timing based on urgency:<hr />  - Urgent: Immediate submission.<hr />  - Non-urgent: 2x absence duration prior.<hr />  - Holiday: 1-2 weeks in advance.<hr />- Example: 8 days advance notice required for leave from Jul 9th-12th.<hr />- Verification involves discussion of workload and resources to prevent project interruptions.<hr />- Approval process includes marking ticket as done, notifying all involved, and updating Google Calendar.<hr />- Client must be informed via email of approved leave, as Basecamp notifications are not sent to them.<hr />- Denial reason documented in the ticket by manager or lead.<hr />- Notify team and client about leave once approved.<hr />- Operations announces holiday period to clients 1-2 weeks in advance.<hr />- Project Manager or Leader sends reminder 2-3 days before holiday.<hr />- Non-urgent responses to clients are prohibited on days off or holidays.

61.title: Understanding your NDA & other agreements
61.description: A guide to the Non-Disclosure, Non-Solicitation, and IP agreements you signed when joining Dwarves.
61.spr_content: - Agreements: Trust foundation between employee, Dwarves, and clients.<hr />- Confidentiality: Essential for protecting business edge and reputation.<hr />  <hr />### Core Promises<hr />1. **Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA)**: <hr />   - Keep client, business, and process information confidential.<hr />   - Obligation persists post-employment.<hr />   <hr />2. **Non-Solicitation**:<hr />   - No recruiting Dwarves staff or soliciting clients for 12 months after departure.<hr /><hr />3. **Intellectual Property (IP)**:<hr />   - Anything created at Dwarves belongs to Dwarves.<hr />   - No personal use of company IP after leaving.<hr /><hr />### Day-to-Day Responsibilities<hr />- **During Employment**:<hr />   - Safeguard sensitive information: secure files, avoid inappropriate sharing, use data legitimately.<hr />   - Clarify sharing uncertainties by asking first.<hr /><hr />- **Post-Employment**:<hr />   - Return all company materials and adhere to NDA and non-solicitation commitments.<hr />   - Prohibited from using or sharing confidential info in future roles.<hr /><hr />### Importance of Compliance<hr />- Violations can lead to:<hr />  - Legal action and financial claims.<hr />  - Court orders restricting activities.<hr />  - Damage to professional reputation.<hr /><hr />### Clarification Steps<hr />- Review signed agreements.<hr />- Discuss with a manager for context.<hr />- Contact HR for questions or clarifications.<hr /><hr />- Employee responsibility: Honor agreements to protect Dwarves’ integrity and future. Trust nurtured through care and integrity in work.

63.spr_content: - Technology evolves in waves; current wave is AI, preceded by DevOps, mobile, and cloud.<hr />- Each wave reshapes client needs and introduces new tools.<hr />- Consulting firm expertise is essential for client success amidst tech changes.<hr />- Mastering current technologies is inadequate; adaptation is crucial.<hr />- Clients rely on our knowledge and future tech insights.<hr />- Falling behind reduces competitive value and utility.<hr />- Core questions drive our adaptation:<hr />  - Which technologies will emerge next?<hr />  - How can we enhance team skills and knowledge?<hr />  - What lessons are derived from previous tech cycles?<hr />- Big tech shifts initiate our structured process at Dwarves.<hr />- Steps of our data-driven approach:<hr />  1. **Gather Information**: Collect data from industry news, trends, internal discussions, and project experiences.<hr />  2. **Understand Data**: Analyze trends and keywords to identify new technologies.<hr />  3. **Make Decisions**: Evaluate insights to determine team skill development, demo creation, or community involvement.<hr />- Important to document each cycle's learning.<hr />- Internal tools like the knowledge base and Tech Radar facilitate:<hr />  - Consistent data collection and organization.<hr />  - Clarity on emerging trends.<hr />  - Informed decisions for tech adoption.<hr />- Aim: Manage tech transitions predictably, support growth, and improve responsiveness to unexpected shifts.<hr />- Collective contribution enhances adaptation process:<hr />  - Share relevant articles, insights, and project experiences.<hr />  - Organize information and suggest tool/process improvements.<hr />- Individual involvement strengthens our future preparedness and collaborative advancement.

focus on innovation and efficiency.<hr />- **Partnerships Over Transactions**: Build lasting relationships based on mutual growth.<hr />- **Everyone Contributes**: Involve every team member in actionable tasks.<hr />- **Effectiveness Over Busyness**: Value meaningful work over a packed schedule.<hr />- **Engineering Discipline**: Systematic approaches prevent complexity and expense.<hr />- **Lean Thinking**: Eliminate waste; 70.title: Quantization for large language models
70.description: As large language models (LLMs) continue to evolve, their parameter counts grow exponentially, with some models reaching trillions of parameters. This exponential growth presents significant challenges for deployment on edge devices and in resource-constrained environments due to extensive memory and computational requirements. Quantization emerges as a crucial technique to reduce model footprint while preserving acceptable performance.
70.spr_content: - LLMs evolve with exponential growth in parameters, reaching trillions.<hr />- Deployment on edge devices faces challenges due to high memory and computational needs.<hr />- Quantization is crucial for reducing model footprints while maintaining performance.<hr />  <hr />- **Quantization Overview**  <hr />  - Transforms weights and activations from high to low precision, e.g., 32-bit to 8-bit.<hr />  - Benefits:  <hr />    - Reduces model size, memory consumption, and storage.<hr />    - Enhances energy efficiency.<hr />  - Precision loss can occur, but remains acceptable within thresholds.<hr />  <hr />- **Quantization Methods**  <hr />  - **Post-training Quantization (PTQ)**: Applied post-training for inference.<hr />  - **Quantization-aware Training (QAT)**: Incorporates quantization during training for accuracy.<hr /><hr />- **Quantization Process**  <hr />  - Types: Linear Quantization (two modes).  <hr />    - **Symmetric**: Zero point is zero. Efficient computationally, possible accuracy loss.<hr />    - **Asymmetric**: Non-zero zero point. Higher accuracy, less efficient computation.<hr /><hr />- **Asymmetric Quantization Formula**  <hr />  - \( q = \text{round}(s * w + z) \)  <hr />  - \( q \): quantized value, \( s \): scale factor, \( w \): original value, \( z \): zero point.<hr />  <hr />- **Steps of Quantization**  <hr />  1. **Data Range Determination**: Identify min/max of dataset.<hr />  2. **Scale Factor Calculation**: <hr />     - \( s = \frac{q_{\text{max}} - q_{\text{min}}}{w_{\text{max}} - w_{\text{min}}} \)<hr />  3. **Zero Point Calculation**: <hr />     - \( z = q_{\text{min}} - \text{round}(s * w_{\text{min}}) \)<hr />  4. **Quantization Application**: Apply the formula to get quantized values.<hr />  5. **De-quantization**: <hr />     - \( w = \frac{q - z}{s} \)<hr />     - Errors from mapping continuous to discrete values: termed quantization error.<hr /><hr />- **Quantized Model File Format**  <hr />  - 2023's GGUF (Generic GPT Unified Format) improves storage and execution for quantized models.<hr />  - Goals: efficiency, compatibility, scalability for varying model architectures.<hr /><hr />- **Model Naming Conventions (e.g., HuggingFace)**  <hr />  - Indicates quantization method and bit representation: `author/{model_name}:q{bits}_{method}`.<hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**  <hr />  - Quantization is pivotal for LLM optimization, facilitating efficient deployment on resource-limited devices.

71.title: Frontend Report March 2025
71.description: March 2025 brings critical frontend updates! Learn about the Next.js security exploit you must patch nows. Explore TypeScript's upcoming 10x speed boost with Corsa, React Router's game-changing middleware, and why prefetching can surprisingly slow down your site. Plus: CSS functions are finally here, new in Chrome 133, Node.js is dropping Corepack, and TanStack Start finds an official deployment home!
71.spr_content: - **Common React Libraries Architecture**: Core logic + bindings (hooks/components). <hr />- **Observer Pattern**: Notifies React of changes; uses `useSyncExternalStore` and custom hooks.<hr />- **Ditching Redux**: Replace with caching; modern React meets state needs with `useState` and custom hooks.<hr />- **React 19 Cache API**: Caches data fetches, reducing redundant requests; improves performance; enables preloading.<hr />- **Next.js Middleware Vulnerability**: CVE-2025-29927; security bypass via `x-middleware-subrequest`; update to secure versions.<hr />- **Next.js 15.2 Updates**: Enhanced error handling; decoupled UI and metadata rendering; faster page loads.<hr />- **Traffic Handling in Next.js**: Pre-rendering limitations; dedicated servers outpace VPS performance in high traffic.<hr />- **Next.js Alternatives**: Custom solutions offer simplicity over Next.js; assess framework fit.<hr />- **Tailwind Trade-offs**: Fast shipping vs. long-term maintainability challenges.<hr />- **CSS Functions**: Introduces real functions; enhances complex logic in styles.<hr />- **Prefetching Pitfalls**: Can harm loading speed; manage via post-load JavaScript hints.<hr />- **React 2025 Trends**: Standardization of Server Components, improved data fetching, rise of Full-Stack React.<hr />- **TypeScript Speed Boost**: New Go-based compiler; promises radical performance improvements.<hr />- **Corepack Discontinuation**: Node.js votes to stop bundling; impacts package manager evolution.<hr />- **TanStack Start Partnership**: Netlify as official deployment partner; zero-config deployments.<hr />- **TanStack Form**: Production-ready for multiple frameworks; focuses on type safety and async validation.<hr />- **React Router v7 Middleware**: Enables route interception for checks and analytics.<hr />- **TypeScript Enhancements**: Granular return type checks; improved Node.js ESM support.<hr />- **Chrome 133 Features**: Enhances `attr()` functionality; enables dynamic styling with container queries.<hr />- **Ongoing JavaScript Fatigue**: Persistent challenges with evolving frameworks and technologies.<hr />- **React Signals Debate**: Discussion on integrating signals into React state management.<hr />- **Local-first Approach**: Future potential for localized data storage, but presents challenges.

72.title: Secure and transparent uptime monitoring with Upptime and GitHub secrets
72.description: Discover how Dwarves Foundation uses Upptime and GitHub Actions for transparent public uptime monitoring while securely keeping tabs on internal services.
72.spr_content: - Importance of uptime monitoring for all services (public and private).<hr />- Necessity of transparency for public services; user trust is vital.<hr />- Need for security and privacy for internal tools and sensitive APIs.<hr />- Risks of exposing internal endpoints: <hr />  - Security vulnerabilities increase with exposure.<hr />  - Internal infrastructure details, if revealed, can be exploited.<hr />  - Unwanted scanning or attacks from bots.<hr />  - Complexity in checks requiring specific authentication details.<hr />- Upptime as the monitoring solution: open-source, GitHub Actions-based.<hr />- GitOps model promotes collaboration and traceable configuration.<hr />- Cost-effective usage of GitHub Actions and self-hosted runners for control.<hr />- Advantages of automation in monitoring and generating status updates.<hr />- `.upptimerc.yml` file centralizes configuration:<hr />  - Public APIs directly listed.<hr />  - Sensitive internal APIs hidden using GitHub Secrets (e.g., `${{ secrets.SECRET_API_URL }}`).<hr />- GitHub Actions workflows manage automation:<hr />  - `uptime.yml`: Runs every 5 minutes, checks URLs, records status, creates Issues on downtime.<hr />  - Daily workflows (`response-time.yml`, `summary.yml`, `site.yml`): Process data and build/update status webpage.<hr />- Dynamic status page (`status.d.foundation`) reflects real-time data:<hr />  - Public data fetched securely from repository.<hr />  - Sensitive API details remain hidden.<hr />- Effective balance between transparent monitoring for public and secure oversight for private services.<hr />- Simple, code-based management enhances overall operational efficiency.

73.title: Labs Team
73.description: This is our Labs team homepage, where we list out the latest advances in our engineering team, our publications, events & workshops, as well as frequently asked questions on who and what team labs are.
73.spr_content: - Labs Team Overview: Passionate about emerging technologies; diverse backgrounds; focused on exploration and understanding for a better future.<hr />  <hr />- Collaboration: Exchange insights; assess innovative applications; partner with consulting teams; hands-on immersion with technologies.<hr /><hr />- Goals: Explore trending technologies; identify potential innovations; roadmap focused on shaping a promising future.<hr /><hr />- Membership Onboarding: Primarily through recommendations; contributions in tech discussions on Discord encouraged; mentoring provided; one-month topic exploration; technical report presentation required.<hr /><hr />- Topic Proposals: Only labs and consulting team members can propose; non-members can share insights on Discord; notable ideas rewarded with ICY tokens.<hr /><hr />- Reward System: ICY tokens awarded based on contribution impact; enhances knowledge base and drives innovation; guidelines available for contribution valuation.<hr /><hr />- Events: Regular catchups to consolidate findings and progress; showcased technologies like DuckDB; demos include NYC taxi data processing and analytics on various data sets.

74.title: Culture Handbook
74.description: Keep learning and growing. We started this team out of software practice advancement.
74.spr_content: - **Continuous Growth**: Emphasize ongoing learning for foundational advancement. Knowledge must evolve for future utility, similar to software.<hr />- **Purpose-Driven**: All actions are rooted in clear purposes, providing tangible value and addressing significance over mere activity.<hr />- **Value of Effectiveness**: Focus on creating maximum value efficiently over mere productivity. Effectiveness is prioritized over busyness.<hr />- **Simplicity in Communication**: Advocate for clarity through simplicity to ensure comprehensibility and accessibility. Solutions should prioritize problem resolution over tool sophistication.<hr />- **Extra Effort**: Strive to exceed expectations, improving incremental aspects of work. Continuous enhancement is essential for better outcomes.<hr />- **Long-Term Thinking**: Consider lasting repercussions of actions; decisions now shape future impacts, both in technology and interpersonal relationships.<hr />- **Pay-It-Forward Culture**: Foster collaboration by mentoring and sharing wisdom, creating a supportive environment for growth.<hr />- **Goal Alignment**: Synchronize efforts towards shared goals, enhancing cohesion and minimizing distractions, while respecting diverse execution styles.<hr />- **Diverse Perspectives**: Value diversity in experiences and viewpoints for enriched understanding and innovation within the team.<hr />- **Collaborative Decision-Making**: Focus on vision and teamwork over individual skillsets, promoting mutual support for collective benefit.<hr />- **Software's Transformative Role**: Acknowledge software’s role in shaping the future, particularly in Web3 and automation. Commitment to leading future advancements is key.<hr />- **Engineering Discipline**: Recognize that disciplined collaboration is essential for effective software engineering; neglecting this leads to inefficiencies.

75.title: How we hire
75.description: Hiring means we need help. We only hire people who tell us what to do, not the other way around. We always look for long-term teammates that why we want to ensure the new hire is a value fit and culture fit.
75.spr_content: - Hiring indicates a need for support and guidance; prioritizing candidates who assert influence rather than seeking direction.<hr />- Focus on cultivating long-term teammates; assess both value and culture fit during the hiring process.<hr />- Recruitment involves four evaluation rounds:<hr />  1. Pre-assessment: 30-minute online test assessing logic, English, and personality without interruptions.<hr />  2. Assignment: Objective task to evaluate skills and approach, providing discussion points for the interview.<hr />  3. Interview: 60-minute session to understand candidate's background and how it aligns with Dwarves' philosophy and work style.<hr />  4. Culture: Casual setting for team to connect with candidates, learning more about them organically.<hr />- "Manager of one" concept: Ideal candidates self-direct, set personal goals, and execute independently. They require minimal oversight and often exceed expectations when left to their own devices.<hr />- Key indicators of a self-sufficient candidate:<hr />  - Previous self-sufficient roles<hr />  - Experience in defining their own job responsibilities<hr />  - Entrepreneurial ventures or initiatives<hr />- Identify candidates with initiative and entrepreneurial spirit; foster their growth to enhance team productivity and reduce management load.<hr />- Sideway Program includes bi-yearly initiatives:<hr />  - Internship program: Open to students from top universities, irrespective of engineering background.<hr />  - Apprenticeships: Six-month paid programs for underrepresented groups in tech, emphasizing real-world project experience.<hr />- No menial tasks; focus on skill development and real-world learning opportunities.<hr />- Referral strategy: Encourage Dwarves to recommend candidates who align with team quality.<hr />- Referral bonus: One month’s salary for employees who successfully refer candidates hired full-time, payable after 90 days of new hire's employment. Employee must be present at the time of bonus issuance.

76.title: Apprentice Program
76.description: Apprenticeship is a six-month earn-and-learn training program; it's a way to learn about being a professional software developer.
76.spr_content: - **Program Overview**: Six-month earn-and-learn apprenticeship for aspiring professional software developers.<hr />- **Learning Method**: Engagement with experienced mentors, hands-on projects, and feedback.<hr />- **Target Audience**: Individuals seeking quality software shipping methods, unclear tech career paths, or transitioning from non-traditional backgrounds.<hr />- **Experience Provided**: Real-world project work, mentoring, professional development, peer feedback, and resources.<hr />- **Topics Covered**:<hr />  - **Engineering Fundamentals**: Multi-language fluency, DevOps principles, software lifecycle management, coding standards like Readme Driven Development.<hr />  - **Design Principles**: Design thinking, UX frameworks, product management, information architecture, visual design principles.<hr />  - **Team Dynamics**: Software team structures, communication strategies, ethics in software engineering.<hr />  - **Quality Assurance**: Measuring software quality, risk management, delivery craftsmanship.<hr />  - **Industry Insights**: Trends in software, historical context, technological evolution, emerging movements in the industry.<hr />  - **Personal Development**: Identifying strengths, software impact, career path exploration.<hr />- **Program Structure**:<hr />  - **Month 1**: Training and preparation; pair programming.<hr />  - **Months 2-4**: Integration into product teams; bi-weekly mentoring; performance reviews.<hr />  - **Month 5-6**: Group studies, technology exploration, project delivery, final evaluations.<hr />- **Application Process**: Open to individuals from diverse backgrounds; requires submitting an application form.

77.title: Dwarves Foundation Apprenticeship: Batch Of 2022
77.description: It’s our second attempt rolling out this program. But the motivation stays the same: Accelerating someone’s current software development skillset.
77.spr_content: - Program aims to accelerate software development skills for engineers with 1+ years of experience.<hr />- Focus: rebuild foundation through practices, real-project scenarios, ethics, and principles.<hr />- High standards maintained; applicant to apprentice ratio is 1:20, from 140+ applicants down to 7 newcomers.<hr />- Key factors for selection: real-work experience, open-mindedness, can-do mindset, learning spirit, proactivity, English skills.<hr />- Feedback from apprentices indicates successful skill advancement.<hr />- Key value generated:<hr />  - Knowledge Upgrade: Learning best practices and systemizing foundational knowledge.<hr />  - Continuous Learning: Apprentices choose areas of interest to research and share.<hr />  - Career Path: Clearer growth paths; some switch specialties (e.g., from DS/Fullstack to Backend).<hr />  - Engineering Principle: Ownership and responsibility are emphasized across experiences.<hr />  - Guiding Method: Peer-to-peer collaboration over traditional mentoring.<hr />  - Teamwork Mindset: Support fostered regardless of role or seniority.<hr />- Future focus: Establishing a data team to address demand for skilled data engineers and analysts.<hr />- Preparation involves research and discussion on data-related challenges.<hr />- Introduction of new cohort of apprentices ready for complex projects.<hr />- Continuous improvement is a priority for future programs.

78.title: QA Engineer
78.description: As an engineer at Dwarves, you will be working closely with a team of talented, kind people and working directly with our clients. There is a lot of freedom to contribute to the quality of the project and improve, or prove yourself
78.spr_content: - **Position**: QA Engineer in Saigon, Dwarves Foundation<hr />- **Company Overview**: Established in 2014, focus on craftsmanship in software development.<hr />- **Team Composition**: 40 members, collaborative environment with developers and designers.<hr />- **Key Attributes of the Company**: Innovation, technology, engineering culture, community impact.<hr />  <hr />- **Requirements**:<hr />  - Carefulness is crucial.<hr />  - Proficiency in Linux or Mac.<hr />  - Familiarity with Agile and Scrum methodologies.<hr />  - Experience with software testing techniques: Regression, E2E, Sanity, Performance.<hr />  - Competence in task management tools (Trello, Jira, Gitlab Board).<hr />  - Knowledge of RESTful API testing tools (Postman, Charles, Insomnia).<hr />  - Experience with Git version control.<hr />  - Basic database skills: PostgreSQL, MySQL, NoSQL.<hr />  - Understanding of UX principles.<hr /><hr />- **Primary Responsibility**:<hr />  - Ensure product quality through requirements analysis, testing, documentation, and process verification.<hr />  - Stay updated with new testing techniques.<hr /><hr />- **Benefits**:<hr />  - **Healthcare**: Comprehensive medical and life insurance.<hr />  - **Work-Life Balance**: Sustainable 40-hour workweek, prioritizing quality over quantity.<hr />  - **Flexible Hours**: No strict start/end times, respect for team meetings.<hr />  - **Employee Stock Options**: Potential ownership stake in the company.<hr />  - **Paid Time Off**: Two weeks of vacation, personal days, honor system for additional time off.<hr /><hr />- **Application Process**:<hr />  - Apply via designated link or email with subject line as specified.<hr />  - Include a short CV, detailed information related to the position, links to public profiles, project portfolio, and references if available.<hr />  - Open to all levels, emphasis on capability over formal education.<hr /><hr />- **Opportunity for Growth**: Apprenticeship Program available for skill enhancement.<hr /><hr />- **Culture**: Non-traditional perks; emphasis on work-life balance and personal development.

79.title: Full-Stack Engineer
79.description: We are looking for a Full-Stack Engineer who is passionate about building scalable, secure, and efficient web applications. The ideal candidate will have a strong understanding of both frontend and backend technologies, and the ability to work across the entire stack.
79.spr_content: - **Hiring Alert**: Full-Stack Engineers position available.<hr />- **Flexibility**: Remote work and impactful projects alongside a skilled team.<hr />- **Company Overview**: Dwarves, a tech-focused firm since 2015, aids in software development and team management, profitable from day one, steadily growing.<hr />- **Achievements**: Goals for 2021 met by October, seeking new engineering talent for future goals.<hr />- **Key Projects**: <hr />  - Ascenda: Revenue growth for financial services with rewards.<hr />  - Fornax AI: Assists startups in pitching ideas to investors.<hr />  - SP Group: Utility services in Singapore and Asia.<hr />- **Web 3.0 Ventures**: <hr />  - Attrace: Referral protocol for crypto.<hr />  - Hedge Foundation: Crypto account management dashboard.<hr />  - Tokenomy: Community VC backed by Indodax.<hr />- **Team Dynamics**: Collaboration with talented, kind people, direct client interaction, freedom to shape project quality.<hr />- **Responsibilities**:<hr />  - Define engineering principles.<hr />  - Design scalable code and conduct system monitoring.<hr />  - Collaborate on problem-solving discussions.<hr />- **Qualifications**:<hr />  - Linux/Mac proficiency, Agile (Scrum) experience.<hr />  - 3+ years in Node.js, strong skills in Firebase, React, Vite, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS.<hr />  - Interest in AI/LLM and fintech.<hr />  - CI/CD experience with Docker workflows, large-scale web services, and system performance.<hr />  - Excellent communication and analytical skills, team collaboration.<hr />- **Work Environment**: Supportive team culture, impactful projects, tech community engagement.<hr />- **Application Call**: Encourage talented individuals to apply or reach out with LinkedIn/CV.<hr />- **Connect**: Join Discord community of over 300 engineers/designers.

/><hr />**Ideal Candidates:**<hr />- Problem solvers: Individuals who thrive in fast-paced environments and embrace complexity.<hr />- Tech enthusiasts: Passion for software craftsmanship and attention to detail.<hr />- Proactive: Ability to take initiative and assume responsibility.<hr />- Cooperative: Kindness and calmness in collaboration within teams. <hr /><hr />**Culture Links:**<hr 81.title: Growth
81.description: At Dwarves, you will be working closely with a team of talented, kind people and working directly with our clients. There is a lot of freedom to contribute to the quality of the project and improve, or prove yourself
81.spr_content: - **Opportunity**: Open marketing position at Dwarves, a tech-savvy company.<hr />- **Team Composition**: Comprised of software engineers, designers, innovation advocates; established in Saigon and Toronto six years ago.<hr />- **Core Mission**: Empower innovations, co-create significant technologies; recognize software as a vital future component.<hr />- **Activities**:<hr />  - Conduct R&D on new technologies for efficient application.<hr />  - Develop software, web apps, SaaS, and cloud platforms.<hr />  - Support startups in launching products.<hr />  - Assist tech communities through projects and events.<hr />- **Marketing Focus**: Inbound strategies to grow audience, deliver value, establish connections.<hr />- **Key Responsibilities**:<hr />  - Boost reputation, drive qualified traffic.<hr />  - Set up pipelines, execute campaigns, monitor results.<hr />  - Manage marketing campaigns from ideation to execution.<hr />  - Prepare reports for senior management.<hr />- **Benefits**:<hr />  - Flat structure, autonomy, remote work.<hr />  - Competitive salary with full pay during probation.<hr />  - Education allowance for work-related learning.<hr />  - KPI rewards and stock options.<hr />- **Interview Process**:<hr />  1. Review and reference check.<hr />  2. Skills assessment test (English, Writing, Logical Thinking).<hr />  3. Team interview with Ops/relevant members.<hr />  4. Immediate offer to selected candidate.<hr />- **Application Process**: Email applications to team@d.foundation with detailed position info, portfolios, and references.<hr />- **Online Presence**: URLs provided for company home, consulting, products, community works, life at Dwarves, manifesto, culture handbook.<hr />- **Flexible Recruitment**: Open to talented individuals beyond listed positions; encourages networking and referrals.

82.title: OGIF Office Hours #20 - Golang weekly, Modeling dynamic object properties, Devbox demo, LLM tracing, Cursor AI editor
82.description: Our latest OGIF session covers key topics such as Go 1.23 and the introduction of Go Notebook, dynamic object modeling inspired by Notion, advanced LLM tracing techniques, Devbox demo and a hands-on look at the Cursor AI code editor. By sharing weekly topics chosen through tags, we foster a collaborative learning environment for our community to grow.
82.spr_content: **Session Overview - Key Points**:<hr /><hr />1. **Introduction and Agenda**: Kickoff meeting with attendance check.<hr />  <hr />2. **Golang Insights**:<hr />   - Release of Go 1.23 discussed.<hr />   - Introduction of Go Notebook: a notebook environment akin to Jupyter for Go.<hr />   - Performance insights on Go Notebook; faster execution reported compared to Jupyter.<hr />   - Mention of "kuam": a tool for handling unnecessary configuration files in projects.<hr /><hr />3. **Dynamic Object Properties**:<hr />   - Explored modeling dynamic objects similar to Notion.<hr />   - Separation of model data and field properties into distinct database tables.<hr />   - Use of an intermediate "value table" to connect tasks with dynamic fields.<hr /><hr />4. **LLM Evaluation and Tracing**:<hr />   - Importance of tracing large language models (LLMs) to ensure output quality.<hr />   - Tools like phonic discussed for evaluating latency and relevance in outputs.<hr />   - Proposed metrics for evaluating performance (latency, accuracy, etc.).<hr /><hr />5. **Cursor AI Tooling**:<hr />   - Introduction of Cursor AI: a new IDE for code generation and context management.<hr />   - Demonstrated features such as command generation and context-aware suggestions.<hr />   - Discussed limitations of Cursor, like manual file creation and context sensitivity.<hr /><hr />6. **Challenges in Dynamic Modeling**:<hr />   - Difficulties managing access permissions for fields across organizations.<hr />   - Addressing the complexities of sorting/filtering and cross-workspace functionality.<hr />   - Issues related to maintaining relationships between entities within the system.<hr /><hr />7. **System Tracing for ML**:<hr />   - Importance of monitoring each processing step in machine learning applications.<hr />   - Methods for adaptive evaluation of model outputs and handling uncertainties.<hr /><hr />8. **Conclusion**:<hr />   - Recap of advantages of emerging tools and methodologies for managing complex systems.<hr />   - Encouragement to explore Cursor AI for enhanced software development efficiency.<hr />

83.title: OGIF Office Hours #22 - Hybrid working, Tech market report, Go commentary weekly, AI demo for Go weekly content production.
83.description: In OGIF 22, we talked about Devbox progress, GReader updates, and using libre chat for artifact management. We also cover optimizing AI system prompts, Go commentary, and key market trends. Plus, we discuss how hybrid work can boost team collaboration and productivity. It’s all about practical tips and knowledge sharing to keep everyone up to speed.
83.spr_content: - **Duration:** 100 minutes meeting.<hr />- **Key Topics Discussed:**<hr />  - Improvements for remote work announced.<hr />  - Market report with project updates provided.<hr />  - Software research and development live demo held.<hr />  - Importance of team collaboration and social connections stressed.<hr />  - New AI tools demonstrated for productivity enhancement.<hr />  - Updates and features on Go programming discussed.<hr />  - Audience engagement was a focus throughout the session.<hr />- **Hybrid Work Implementation:**<hr />  - Starting next week, hybrid work options will be enabled.<hr />  - Office upgrades for distractions, equipped with Apple Studio Displays and Herman Miller chairs.<hr />  - Optional use of office spaces for more focused work.<hr />  - Social connections emphasized to boost productivity, especially during project finalization.<hr />- **Daily Check-In Feature:**<hr />  - Incentivized with ICY rewards for participation.<hr />  - Two-week trial phase planned, prioritizing those transitioning to hybrid work.<hr />- **Software Tools:**<hr />  - Discussion about the new "Script" tool for Go programming, enabling scriptwriting and code embedding.<hr />  - Go CH version 1.23 introduced, with the option to toggle telemetry data collection.<hr />  - Discussion of advancements in AI tools: CR 3.5 Sonnet for system upgrades, resource-saving ping system in Cross, and OpenAI's TT4 model ensuring output compliance with defined schemas.<hr />- **Future Prospects & Developments:**<hr />  - Anticipated integration of AI into mainstream business functions.<hr />  - Price reductions expected for AI services over time, enhancing accessibility and usability.<hr />  - Emphasis on building internal capacities and automation for software development.<hr />- **Conclusion:**<hr />  - Continuous adaptation and exploration of new technologies urged.<hr />  - Encouragement to leverage AI tools for efficiency in processes and outputs.<hr />  - Future discussions and tests scheduled to assess developments and user proficiency.

84.title: OGIF Office Hours #23 - Go weekly, Frontend report, Hybrid working support, and AI mixture agent
84.description: In OGIF Office Hour 23 covered a variety of topics, including updates on Golang Weekly and its use in enterprise environments, comparing Go with Java and C++. The session explored the latest trends in React 19 AC, Next.js, and CSS Grid, alongside new form-building tools. Additionally, the team discussed productivity enhancements using AI-driven solutions like mixture agents, while introducing upcoming tests and hybrid work support.
84.spr_content: 1. **Financial Report & Golang Weekly**: Present August financial performance; discuss updates on Golang blog and survey feedback.<hr />2. **Go in Enterprises**: Evaluate Go's enterprise suitability; compare Java vs. C; analyze transition benefits/challenges to Go in large organizations.<hr />3. **Technology Trends & Updates**: Highlight React 19 AC and Next.js updates; explore CSS Grid vs. Flexbox; mention JavaScript improvements and form-building tool fity.<hr />4. **Team Productivity Enhancements**: Introduce mixture agents and EOM for optimizing learning; demonstrate applications in language learning and RP trading.<hr />5. **AI-Driven Solutions**: Utilize AI comments and system prompts for workflow automation; implement check-in features for hybrid work settings.<hr />6. **Upcoming Tests and Team Building**: Design efficiency tests using AI; plan team outings and support for returning to the office.<hr /><hr />- Go maturing for enterprise adoption; still behind Java; new enterprises may transition to Go.<hr />- Java vs. C++ comparison: Java's simplicity and stability; C++ complexity regarding memory management.<hr />- Enterprise language preferences: Java's long-standing appeal; community discussions favoring Java and C++.<hr />- Explore reasons to switch from Java to Go; address Go's solutions to Java’s shortcomings.<hr />- Discuss development of AI Comment chatbot; focus on input/output management for enhanced knowledge extraction.<hr />- Evaluate effectiveness of AI tools; strike balance between complexity and user reliance on intuitive design.<hr />- Encourage team engagement through hybrid office days and active learning via AI.<hr /><hr />- Anticipate 2024 programming language trends; Python leads, followed by Java and JavaScript.<hr />- Team collaboration emphasized; promote proactive AI tool usage.<hr />- Future projects to include hands-on coding examples; establish workflows comparing traditional vs. AI-assisted methods.

Data cleaning and analysis using CSV files.<hr />  - Infographic generation from backend technology data.<hr />  - Figma to code conversion for UI components.<hr />  - AI integration for automating repetitive tasks.<hr />  - Team collaboration and knowledge sharing. <hr />- **Agent Zero Features**:<hr />  - Utilizes natural language commands to generate code.<hr />  - Handles data processing tasks such as CSV manipulation and infographics creation.<hr />  - Searches and augments backend technologies from multiple sources.<hr />  - Capable of fixing errors autonomously during the coding process.<hr />  - Integrates with libraries like Matplotlib for graphical output.<hr />  - Keeps a cache of tools for efficient re-use.<hr />- **AI Tools Discussion**:<hr />  - The role of AI in automating data cleaning and analysis.<hr />  - Potential for integrating AI in Figma for code generation.<hr />  - Discussion of using AI for query generation in custom programming languages (e.g., AQL).<hr />- **Challenges Identified**:<hr />  - Debugging AI-generated code and managing complex tasks.<hr />  - Understanding variable definitions in querying systems.<hr />  - User adoption hurdles regarding new programming languages and interfaces.<hr />- **Future Outlook**:<hr />  - Deeper exploration into topics like MapReduce for Data Engineering.<hr />  - Continued development and iteration of Agent Zero's capabilities.<hr />  - Enhancements in user experience for BI dashboards integrating AI-generated queries.<hr />- **Team Dynamics**: <hr />  - Emphasis on contributions from various teams (Engineering, Product) during tool development.<hr />  - Encouragement of in-person collaboration to enhance knowledge transfer.<hr />  - Implementation of a check-in system fostering team presence in the office. <hr />- **Incentives Structure**: Introduction of ICY points system to motivate office attendance and collaboration.

87.title: OGIF Office Hours #26 - Product Design Commentary, Go Weekly, Trading App Case Study, Chatbot Evaluations, and Announcement for Essay Assignments
87.description: In this Office Hours, Nam Bui shared product design insights on the Sparkle icon in AI and onboarding, Phat covered Go tools Prep and War Zero, and Hoang discussed chatbot evaluations. Anh presented a case study on AI-driven user research for Kafi. Management announced AI essay assignments tied to the year-end trip and performance reviews.
87.spr_content: 1. **Nam Bui on Product Design**:<hr />   - Introduced the Sparkle icon, prevalent in AI apps.<hr />   - Discussed onboarding practices for new AI users.<hr />   - Highlighted usage examples of Sparkle in applications like Plane Finder, Ulta, Google Meet, Figma, Miro, Dovetail, and Nylas, emphasizing its association with AI capabilities.<hr /><hr />2. **Phat on Go Weekly Commentary**:<hr />   - Discussed "Prep," a compile-time evaluation tool in Go, enhancing performance by evaluating computations at compile time.<hr />   - Explained "War Zero," a database-compatible web assembly runtime, its usage and compatibility with basic databases.<hr />   - Evaluated pros and cons of these tools.<hr /><hr />3. **Hoang on Chatbot Evaluation**:<hr />   - Proposed an evaluation method using simulated users and evaluators.<hr />   - Explained the implementation setup and metrics for assessing chatbot interactions.<hr /><hr />4. **Anh on Kafi Stock Trading App Case Study**:<hr />   - Outlined research and redesign of Kafi’s stock trading app.<hr />   - Detailed user research process, problem analysis, and proposed AI-driven solutions to improve user experience.<hr /><hr />5. **Management Announcements**:<hr />   - Required submission of two essays and a practical assignment on AI, with specified topics and deadlines as conditions for a year-end trip and performance review.<hr />   - Emphasized controlled use of AI in work practices.<hr /><hr />6. **Project and Research Updates**:<hr />   - Discussed exploration of multi-agent systems, knowledge routing, semantic projection, and the need for understanding new software architectures.<hr /><hr />7. **Importance of AI Application**:<hr />   - Stressed proactive learning in AI to adapt to evolving industry trends.<hr /><hr />8. **Job Market Observations**:<hr />   - Analyzed shifts in job market dynamics, particularly for junior and mid-level positions.

88.title: OGIF Office Hours #27 - Go Weekly, Frontend Report Sep, UX Guide to Prompt with AI, Computing the Union of Two Finite Automata
88.description: In OGIF office hour 27, covering presentations on UX Guide to Prompt with AI, computing the union of finite automata, and other topics including Go Weekly and Frontend Report for September.
88.spr_content: 1. **Nam's UX Presentation on AI Prompting**  <hr />   - Overview of AI-human interaction trends.  <hr />   - Introduction of the "RACE" framework: Role, Action, Context, Expectation.  <hr />   - New methods to enhance AI UX:  <hr />     - Context Through Rephrasing: Links previous context for coherent follow-up questions.  <hr />     - Implicit Referencing: Assumes context in user queries.  <hr />     - Continue Conversation: Enables natural dialogue flow.  <hr />     - Racing and AI Scoring: Context-based options improve user interaction.  <hr />     - System Prompting: Directs AI to user-defined goals for accurate output.  <hr />   - Emphasis on improving overall UX beyond speed and accuracy.<hr /><hr />2. **Minh's Finite Automata Presentation**  <hr />   - Applications of finite state machines in programming.  <hr />   - Importance in input validation (e.g., regex for emails/numbers).  <hr />   - Use in event-driven systems and event buttons, demonstrated using Go source code.<hr /><hr />3. **Phat's Commentary on Go Programming**  <hr />   - Overview of recent Go language developments.  <hr />   - Discussion of notable updates and changes.  <hr />   - Insights into the Go programming community.<hr /><hr />4. **Lap's Frontend Report for September**  <hr />   - Overview of recent frontend technology trends.  <hr />   - Discussion of notable frameworks, libraries, and tools.  <hr />   - Insights into the frontend community.<hr /><hr />5. **Key Insights from the Transcripts**  <hr />   - Importance of seamless AI interactions in UX design.  <hr />   - Need for computational efficiency when combining finite automata.  <hr />   - Trends in Go and React indicate shifting preferences in tech stacks.  <hr />   - Community sentiment reflects a desire for improved server-side solutions over client-side heaviness.  <hr />   - Increased focus on mathematical and logical principles in software development is emergent.
